diseases.name: Early Blight
diseases.description: Dark brown lesions with concentric rings (target-like) on lower leaves spreading upward
diseases.treatment: Apply appropriate Chlorothalonil, Azoxystrobin or organic options: Copper hydroxide, Neem oil

preventive_measures: Remove and destroy infected plant parts immediately
Apply appropriate fungicide/bactericide for the specific pathogen
Improve growing conditions to reduce disease pressure
Use floating row covers until flowering to prevent early pest damage
Install reflective mulch to repel aphids and whiteflies (50% reduction)
Apply calcium nitrate foliar spray weekly to prevent blossom end rot
Maintain optimal plant spacing for good air circulation (prevents 85% of fungal issues)
Use drip irrigation instead of overhead (reduces disease spread by 40%)
Maintain soil pH between 6.0-6.8 for optimal nutrient availability

fertilizer_recommendations.name: Compost Tea
fertilizer_recommendations.description: Liquid extract of compost containing beneficial microbes, nutrients, and organic compounds that improve soil biology and plant health.
fertilizer_recommendations.application: Apply as soil drench (5 gal/100 sq ft) or foliar spray (diluted 1:5) every 2-4 weeks.
fertilizer_recommendations.conditions: All plants, especially when microbial activity is desired
fertilizer_recommendations.scientific_backing: Research demonstrates 30-50% increase in beneficial soil microbes after application

fertilizer_recommendations.name: Calcium Nitrate
fertilizer_recommendations.description: Provides readily available nitrogen and prevents blossom end rot by supplying calcium during fruit development.
fertilizer_recommendations.application: Apply 1-2 tbsp/gal as foliar spray or 1 lb/100 sq ft as soil application every 2 weeks during fruiting.
fertilizer_recommendations.conditions: For fruiting stage, especially when blossom end rot is a concern
fertilizer_recommendations.scientific_backing: Reduces blossom end rot incidence by up to 80% in field trials

fertilizer_recommendations.name: Phosphorus-Potassium Booster
fertilizer_recommendations.description: Lower nitrogen with higher phosphorus and potassium to encourage flowering and fruit development instead of excessive vegetative growth.
fertilizer_recommendations.application: Apply 1 lb/100 sq ft at first flower cluster formation and repeat every 3-4 weeks.
fertilizer_recommendations.conditions: When plants are transitioning from vegetative to flowering stage
fertilizer_recommendations.scientific_backing: Improves fruit set by 25-30% compared to high-nitrogen fertilizers

diseases.name: Early Blight
diseases.description: Dark brown lesions with concentric rings (target-like) on lower leaves spreading upward
diseases.treatment: Apply appropriate Chlorothalonil, Azoxystrobin or organic options: Copper hydroxide, Neem oil

detailed_info.symptoms: Dark brown spots with concentric rings on older leaves ('target board' appearance). Yellowing of leaves leading to defoliation
detailed_info.causes: Fungus (Alternaria solani) persists in soil and plant debris. Spread facilitated by splashing water and wind
detailed_info.treatment: Spray Chlorothalonil or Mancozeb @ 2–2.5 g/L. Use Azoxystrobin as systemic option
detailed_info.prevention: Practice crop rotation, remove plant debris after harvest, ensure balanced fertilization (especially nitrogen and potassium)

preventive_measures: Remove and destroy infected plant parts immediately
Apply appropriate fungicide/bactericide for the specific pathogen
Improve growing conditions to reduce disease pressure
Prune to 2-3 main stems for optimal airflow (reduces disease pressure 30%)
Apply calcium nitrate foliar spray weekly to prevent blossom end rot
Stake plants at 45° angle for maximum sun exposure and air flow
Maintain soil pH between 6.0-6.8 for optimal nutrient availability
Water at the base in early morning (reduces leaf wetness duration by 60%)
Introduce beneficial insects 2 weeks before expected pest outbreaks

fertilizer_recommendations.name: Rock Phosphate
fertilizer_recommendations.description: Slow-release source of phosphorus that becomes available over 2-3 years. Ideal for building long-term soil phosphorus reserves.
fertilizer_recommendations.application: Apply 5-10 lbs per 100 sq ft and incorporate into soil before planting. Does not dissolve in water.
fertilizer_recommendations.conditions: Soils testing low in phosphorus, perennial crops
fertilizer_recommendations.scientific_backing: Long-term studies show cumulative benefits over 3-5 year period

diseases.name: Purple Blotch
diseases.description: Small, water-soaked lesions that quickly develop purple centers and yellow margins
diseases.treatment: Apply appropriate Mancozeb, Chlorothalonil or organic options: Garlic extract spray, Neem oil

detailed_info.symptoms: Small water-soaked lesions on leaves that turn purplish with yellow halos
detailed_info.causes: Warm and humid conditions, caused by fungus Alternaria porri
detailed_info.treatment: Spray Mancozeb (0.25%) or Chlorothalonil (0.2%) every 10-15 days
detailed_info.prevention: Ensure good field sanitation and crop rotation

pests.name: Aphids
pests.scientific_name: Various species (e.g., Aphis gossypii, Myzus persicae)
pests.description: Small (1-3mm), soft-bodied insects, often clustered on new growth, various colors. Stunted growth, leaf curling, transmission of plant viruses, honeydew secretion
pests.treatment: Chemical control: Imidacloprid, Acetamiprid. Organic options: Neem oil, Insecticidal soap

preventive_measures: Remove and destroy infected plant debris after harvest
Apply fungicides containing mancozeb or chlorothalonil at 7-10 day intervals
Use UV-reflective mulch which repels aphids by 60%
Apply flonicamid when populations exceed 50 aphids/leaf
Practice shallow cultivation to avoid damaging shallow root systems
Apply sulfur-containing fertilizers to enhance pungency and disease resistance
Plant disease-free sets or transplants from certified sources
Use drip irrigation instead of overhead (reduces disease spread by 40%)
Record pest/disease occurrences to predict and prevent future outbreaks
Maintain optimal plant spacing for good air circulation (prevents 85% of fungal issues)

fertilizer_recommendations.name: Rock Phosphate
fertilizer_recommendations.description: Slow-release source of phosphorus that becomes available over 2-3 years. Ideal for building long-term soil phosphorus reserves.
fertilizer_recommendations.application: Apply 5-10 lbs per 100 sq ft and incorporate into soil before planting. Does not dissolve in water.
fertilizer_recommendations.conditions: Soils testing low in phosphorus, perennial crops
fertilizer_recommendations.scientific_backing: Long-term studies show cumulative benefits over 3-5 year period

fertilizer_recommendations.name: Nitrogen-Sulfur Blend
fertilizer_recommendations.description: Provides nitrogen for leaf growth and sulfur which is essential for onion flavor development and disease resistance.
fertilizer_recommendations.application: Side-dress 1 lb/100 ft row at 3-leaf stage and again 3-4 weeks later.
fertilizer_recommendations.conditions: Early to mid-growth stage onions
fertilizer_recommendations.scientific_backing: Sulfur application increases pyruvic acid content by 30%, enhancing flavor

fertilizer_recommendations.name: Low-N, High-K Blend
fertilizer_recommendations.description: Lower nitrogen with higher potassium for bulb development phase. Reducing nitrogen prevents excess leaf growth that can delay bulbing.
fertilizer_recommendations.application: Apply 1 lb/100 ft row when bulbs begin to form, typically 6-8 weeks after planting.
fertilizer_recommendations.conditions: During bulb formation stage
fertilizer_recommendations.scientific_backing: Potassium application at bulbing improves storage quality by 25-40%

suitability.onion: Poor suitability for onions without significant amendments. Requires intensive management.
suitability.tomato: Moderate suitability with irrigation, mulching, and nutrient management.

results.recommendations:
### Recommendations for Coastal Sandy Soil:
            
            1. **Water Management:**
               - Install drip irrigation systems
               - Use mulching extensively to conserve moisture
               - Apply hydrogels for improving water retention
            
            2. **Soil Improvement:**
               - Add clay or silt-rich soil to improve texture
               - Incorporate very high rates of organic matter (30-40 tonnes/ha)
               - Use cocopeat or vermiculite as soil amendments
            
            3. **Crop-Specific Recommendations:**
               - **For Onions:** Consider container or raised bed cultivation
               - **For Tomatoes:** Use salt-tolerant varieties and mulching

diseases.name: Downy Mildew
diseases.description: Pale-green to yellow elongated patches on leaves with gray-violet fuzzy growth
diseases.treatment: Apply appropriate Metalaxyl, Chlorothalonil or organic options: Copper hydroxide, Potassium bicarbonate

pests.name: Tomato Hornworm
pests.scientific_name: Manduca quinquemaculata
pests.description: Large (up to 10cm) green caterpillars with diagonal white stripes and a horn-like projection. Extensive defoliation, feeding on fruits, significant damage to tomato plants
pests.treatment: Chemical control: Carbaryl, Permethrin. Organic options: Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt), Handpicking

pests.name: Thrips
pests.scientific_name: Various species (e.g., Thrips tabaci, Frankliniella occidentalis)
pests.description: Tiny (1-2mm), slender insects with fringed wings, difficult to see without magnification. Silvery stippling on leaves, leaf distortion, scarring of fruits, transmission of viruses
pests.treatment: Chemical control: Spinosad, Spinetoram. Organic options: Spinosad, Neem oil

preventive_measures: Use drip irrigation rather than overhead watering
Plant resistant varieties where available
Introduce predatory mites like Amblyseius swirskii
Use reflective mulch to reduce landing rates
Implement physical barriers or traps for the specific pest
Apply appropriate insecticide following IPM principles
Enhance natural enemy populations through habitat management
Practice shallow cultivation to avoid damaging shallow root systems
Maintain consistent soil moisture to prevent splitting and secondary infections
Cure harvested bulbs properly with good ventilation to prevent storage diseases

fertilizer_recommendations.name: Balanced NPK (10-10-10)
fertilizer_recommendations.description: Provides equal parts nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), and potassium (K). Nitrogen promotes leaf growth, phosphorus supports root and flower development, potassium enhances overall plant health.
fertilizer_recommendations.application: Apply 2-3 lbs per 100 sq ft before planting and side-dress during active growth. Water thoroughly after application.
fertilizer_recommendations.conditions: General purpose for most plants during vegetative growth
fertilizer_recommendations.scientific_backing: University studies show balanced NPK improves yield by 15-20% over unfertilized controls

fertilizer_recommendations.conditions: Early to mid-growth stage onions
fertilizer_recommendations.scientific_backing: Sulfur application increases pyruvic acid content by 30%, enhancing flavor

detailed_info.treatment: Spray Chlorothalonil or Mancozeb @ 2–2.5 g/L. Use Azoxystrobin as systemic option
detailed_info.prevention: Practice crop rotation, remove plant debris after harvest, ensure balanced fertilization (especially nitrogen and potassium)

preventive_measures: Apply irrigation in morning so leaves dry quickly

diseases.name: Early Blight

diseases.treatment: Apply appropriate Chlorothalonil, Azoxystrobin or organic options: Copper hydroxide, Neem oil

detailed_info.symptoms: Dark brown spots with concentric rings on older leaves ('target board' appearance). Yellowing of leaves leading to defoliation
detailed_info.causes: Fungus (Alternaria solani) persists in soil and plant debris. Spread facilitated by splashing water and wind
detailed_info.treatment: Spray Chlorothalonil or Mancozeb @ 2–2.5 g/L. Use Azoxystrobin as systemic option
detailed_info.prevention: Practice crop rotation, remove plant debris after harvest, ensure balanced fertilization (especially nitrogen and potassium)

Use floating row covers until flowering to prevent early pest damage

diseases.name: Late Blight
diseases.description: Dark, water-soaked lesions on leaves, stems and fruits with white fuzzy growth
diseases.treatment: Apply appropriate Chlorothalonil, Mancozeb or organic options: Copper formulations, Bacillus subtilis

detailed_info.symptoms: Water-soaked lesions on leaves, stems, and fruits. White mold growth under leaves in humid conditions
detailed_info.causes: Oomycete pathogen Phytophthora infestans thrives in cool, wet weather. Spores spread via wind and rain
detailed_info.treatment: Apply fungicides like Mancozeb + Metalaxyl, Phosphoric acid-based foliar fertilizers
detailed_info.prevention: Remove and destroy infected plants immediately, avoid overhead watering to reduce leaf wetness

results.characteristics:
- High sand content (>70%)
            - Very low water retention
            - Poor in organic matter and nutrients
            - Excellent drainage (often excessive)
            - May have salinity issues
            - pH range: 7.0-8.5 (neutral to alkaline)

suitability.onion: Poor suitability for onions without significant amendments. Requires intensive management.
suitability.tomato: Moderate suitability with irrigation, mulching, and nutrient management.

results.recommendations:
### Recommendations for Coastal Sandy Soil:
            
            1. **Water Management:**
               - Install drip irrigation systems
               - Use mulching extensively to conserve moisture
               - Apply hydrogels for improving water retention
            
            2. **Soil Improvement:**
               - Add clay or silt-rich soil to improve texture
               - Incorporate very high rates of organic matter (30-40 tonnes/ha)
               - Use cocopeat or vermiculite as soil amendments
            
            3. **Crop-Specific Recommendations:**
               - **For Onions:** Consider container or raised bed cultivation
               - **For Tomatoes:** Use salt-tolerant varieties and mulching

diseases.name: Early Blight
diseases.description: Dark brown lesions with concentric rings (target-like) on lower leaves spreading upward
diseases.treatment: Apply appropriate Chlorothalonil, Azoxystrobin or organic options: Copper hydroxide, Neem oil

detailed_info.symptoms: Dark brown spots with concentric rings on older leaves ('target board' appearance). Yellowing of leaves leading to defoliation
detailed_info.causes: Fungus (Alternaria solani) persists in soil and plant debris. Spread facilitated by splashing water and wind
detailed_info.treatment: Spray Chlorothalonil or Mancozeb @ 2–2.5 g/L. Use Azoxystrobin as systemic option
detailed_info.prevention: Practice crop rotation, remove plant debris after harvest, ensure balanced fertilization (especially nitrogen and potassium)

pests.scientific_name: Manduca quinquemaculata
pests.description: Large (up to 10cm) green caterpillars with diagonal white stripes and a horn-like projection. Extensive defoliation, feeding on fruits, significant damage to tomato plants
pests.treatment: Chemical control: Carbaryl, Permethrin. Organic options: Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt), Handpicking

results.recommendations:
### Recommendations for Coastal Sandy Soil:
            
            1. **Water Management:**
               - Install drip irrigation systems
               - Use mulching extensively to conserve moisture
               - Apply hydrogels for improving water retention
            
            2. **Soil Improvement:**
               - Add clay or silt-rich soil to improve texture
               - Incorporate very high rates of organic matter (30-40 tonnes/ha)
               - Use cocopeat or vermiculite as soil amendments
            
            3. **Crop-Specific Recommendations:**
               - **For Onions:** Consider container or raised bed cultivation
               - **For Tomatoes:** Use salt-tolerant varieties and mulching

diseases.name: Late Blight
diseases.description: Dark, water-soaked lesions on leaves, stems and fruits with white fuzzy growth
diseases.treatment: Apply appropriate Chlorothalonil, Mancozeb or organic options: Copper formulations, Bacillus subtilis

detailed_info.symptoms: Water-soaked lesions on leaves, stems, and fruits. White mold growth under leaves in humid conditions
detailed_info.causes: Oomycete pathogen Phytophthora infestans thrives in cool, wet weather. Spores spread via wind and rain
detailed_info.treatment: Apply fungicides like Mancozeb + Metalaxyl, Phosphoric acid-based foliar fertilizers
detailed_info.prevention: Remove and destroy infected plants immediately, avoid overhead watering to reduce leaf wetness

pests.name: Tomato Hornworm
pests.scientific_name: Manduca quinquemaculata
pests.description: Large (up to 10cm) green caterpillars with diagonal white stripes and a horn-like projection. Extensive defoliation, feeding on fruits, significant damage to tomato plants
pests.treatment: Chemical control: Carbaryl, Permethrin. Organic options: Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt), Handpicking

pests.name: Thrips
pests.scientific_name: Various species (e.g., Thrips tabaci, Frankliniella occidentalis)
pests.description: Tiny (1-2mm), slender insects with fringed wings, difficult to see without magnification. Silvery stippling on leaves, leaf distortion, scarring of fruits, transmission of viruses
pests.treatment: Chemical control: Spinosad, Spinetoram. Organic options: Spinosad, Neem oil

preventive_measures: Apply copper fungicides preventatively when Smith Periods occur (2+ days >10°C with 10+ hrs leaf wetness)
Apply phosphorous acid fungicides which show 85% efficacy
Avoid planting near known host plants like onions and garlic
Apply spinosad-based products when population exceeds threshold
Implement physical barriers or traps for the specific pest
Apply appropriate insecticide following IPM principles
Enhance natural enemy populations through habitat management
Stake plants at 45° angle for maximum sun exposure and air flow
Prune to 2-3 main stems for optimal airflow (reduces disease pressure 30%)
Install reflective mulch to repel aphids and whiteflies (50% reduction)

fertilizer_recommendations.name: Balanced NPK (10-10-10)
fertilizer_recommendations.description: Provides equal parts nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), and potassium (K). Nitrogen promotes leaf growth, phosphorus supports root and flower development, potassium enhances overall plant health.
fertilizer_recommendations.application: Apply 2-3 lbs per 100 sq ft before planting and side-dress during active growth. Water thoroughly after application.
fertilizer_recommendations.conditions: General purpose for most plants during vegetative growth
fertilizer_recommendations.scientific_backing: University studies show balanced NPK improves yield by 15-20% over unfertilized controls

fertilizer_recommendations.name: Calcium Nitrate
fertilizer_recommendations.description: Provides readily available nitrogen and prevents blossom end rot by supplying calcium during fruit development.
fertilizer_recommendations.application: Apply 1-2 tbsp/gal as foliar spray or 1 lb/100 sq ft as soil application every 2 weeks during fruiting.
fertilizer_recommendations.conditions: For fruiting stage, especially when blossom end rot is a concern
fertilizer_recommendations.scientific_backing: Reduces blossom end rot incidence by up to 80% in field trials

fertilizer_recommendations.name: Phosphorus-Potassium Booster
fertilizer_recommendations.description: Lower nitrogen with higher phosphorus and potassium to encourage flowering and fruit development instead of excessive vegetative growth.
fertilizer_recommendations.application: Apply 1 lb/100 sq ft at first flower cluster formation and repeat every 3-4 weeks.
fertilizer_recommendations.conditions: When plants are transitioning from vegetative to flowering stage
fertilizer_recommendations.scientific_backing: Improves fruit set by 25-30% compared to high-nitrogen fertilizers

fertilizer_recommendations.application: Apply 2-3 lbs per 100 sq ft before planting and side-dress during active growth. Water thoroughly after application.
fertilizer_recommendations.conditions: General purpose for most plants during vegetative growth
fertilizer_recommendations.scientific_backing: University studies show balanced NPK improves yield by 15-20% over unfertilized controls

diseases.name: Powdery Mildew
diseases.description: Symptoms of Powdery Mildew observed on the plant
diseases.treatment: Consult a local agricultural expert for specific treatment options

pests.name: Spider Mites
pests.scientific_name: Various species (e.g., Tetranychus urticae)
pests.description: Tiny (0.5mm) arachnids, often forming webbing on plants, various colors. Fine stippling on leaves, yellowing or bronzing of foliage, webbing on plants
pests.treatment: Chemical control: Abamectin, Bifenazate. Organic options: Predatory mites, Neem oil

preventive_measures: Apply potassium bicarbonate (3g/L) at first sign - 70% control
Time plantings to avoid peak spore dispersal periods
Implement physical barriers or traps for the specific pest
Apply appropriate insecticide following IPM principles
Enhance natural enemy populations through habitat management
Water at the base in early morning (reduces leaf wetness duration by 60%)
Implement strict sanitation: disinfect tools with 70% alcohol between plants
Maintain soil pH between 6.0-6.8 for optimal nutrient availability

fertilizer_recommendations.name: Compost Tea
fertilizer_recommendations.description: Liquid extract of compost containing beneficial microbes, nutrients, and organic compounds that improve soil biology and plant health.
fertilizer_recommendations.application: Apply as soil drench (5 gal/100 sq ft) or foliar spray (diluted 1:5) every 2-4 weeks.
fertilizer_recommendations.conditions: All plants, especially when microbial activity is desired
fertilizer_recommendations.scientific_backing: Research demonstrates 30-50% increase in beneficial soil microbes after application

fertilizer_recommendations.name: Rock Phosphate
fertilizer_recommendations.description: Slow-release source of phosphorus that becomes available over 2-3 years. Ideal for building long-term soil phosphorus reserves.
fertilizer_recommendations.application: Apply 5-10 lbs per 100 sq ft and incorporate into soil before planting. Does not dissolve in water.
fertilizer_recommendations.conditions: Soils testing low in phosphorus, perennial crops
fertilizer_recommendations.scientific_backing: Long-term studies show cumulative benefits over 3-5 year period

fertilizer_recommendations.name: Balanced NPK (10-10-10)
fertilizer_recommendations.description: Provides equal parts nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), and potassium (K). Nitrogen promotes leaf growth, phosphorus supports root and flower development, potassium enhances overall plant health.
fertilizer_recommendations.application: Apply 2-3 lbs per 100 sq ft before planting and side-dress during active growth. Water thoroughly after application.
fertilizer_recommendations.conditions: General purpose for most plants during vegetative growth

diseases.name: Early Blight
diseases.description: Dark brown lesions with concentric rings (target-like) on lower leaves spreading upward
diseases.treatment: Apply appropriate Chlorothalonil, Azoxystrobin or organic options: Copper hydroxide, Neem oil

detailed_info.symptoms: Dark brown spots with concentric rings on older leaves ('target board' appearance). Yellowing of leaves leading to defoliation
detailed_info.causes: Fungus (Alternaria solani) persists in soil and plant debris. Spread facilitated by splashing water and wind
detailed_info.treatment: Spray Chlorothalonil or Mancozeb @ 2–2.5 g/L. Use Azoxystrobin as systemic option
detailed_info.prevention: Practice crop rotation, remove plant debris after harvest, ensure balanced fertilization (especially nitrogen and potassium)

pests.name: Tomato Hornworm
pests.scientific_name: Manduca quinquemaculata
pests.description: Large (up to 10cm) green caterpillars with diagonal white stripes and a horn-like projection. Extensive defoliation, feeding on fruits, significant damage to tomato plants
pests.treatment: Chemical control: Carbaryl, Permethrin. Organic options: Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt), Handpicking

pests.name: Thrips
pests.scientific_name: Various species (e.g., Thrips tabaci, Frankliniella occidentalis)
pests.description: Tiny (1-2mm), slender insects with fringed wings, difficult to see without magnification. Silvery stippling on leaves, leaf distortion, scarring of fruits, transmission of viruses
pests.treatment: Chemical control: Spinosad, Spinetoram. Organic options: Spinosad, Neem oil

preventive_measures: Use blue sticky traps to monitor and trap adults
Introduce predatory mites like Amblyseius swirskii
Remove and destroy infected plant parts immediately
Apply appropriate fungicide/bactericide for the specific pathogen
Improve growing conditions to reduce disease pressure
Implement physical barriers or traps for the specific pest
Apply appropriate insecticide following IPM principles
Enhance natural enemy populations through habitat management
Prune to 2-3 main stems for optimal airflow (reduces disease pressure 30%)
Stake plants at 45° angle for maximum sun exposure and air flow

fertilizer_recommendations.name: Rock Phosphate
fertilizer_recommendations.description: Slow-release source of phosphorus that becomes available over 2-3 years. Ideal for building long-term soil phosphorus reserves.
fertilizer_recommendations.application: Apply 5-10 lbs per 100 sq ft and incorporate into soil before planting. Does not dissolve in water.
fertilizer_recommendations.conditions: Soils testing low in phosphorus, perennial crops
fertilizer_recommendations.scientific_backing: Long-term studies show cumulative benefits over 3-5 year period

fertilizer_recommendations.name: Calcium Nitrate
fertilizer_recommendations.description: Provides readily available nitrogen and prevents blossom end rot by supplying calcium during fruit development.
fertilizer_recommendations.application: Apply 1-2 tbsp/gal as foliar spray or 1 lb/100 sq ft as soil application every 2 weeks during fruiting.
fertilizer_recommendations.conditions: For fruiting stage, especially when blossom end rot is a concern
fertilizer_recommendations.scientific_backing: Reduces blossom end rot incidence by up to 80% in field trials

fertilizer_recommendations.name: Phosphorus-Potassium Booster
fertilizer_recommendations.description: Lower nitrogen with higher phosphorus and potassium to encourage flowering and fruit development instead of excessive vegetative growth.
fertilizer_recommendations.application: Apply 1 lb/100 sq ft at first flower cluster formation and repeat every 3-4 weeks.
fertilizer_recommendations.conditions: When plants are transitioning from vegetative to flowering stage
fertilizer_recommendations.scientific_backing: Improves fruit set by 25-30% compared to high-nitrogen fertilizers

results.recommendations:
### Recommendations for Coastal Sandy Soil:
            
            1. **Water Management:**
               - Install drip irrigation systems
               - Use mulching extensively to conserve moisture
               - Apply hydrogels for improving water retention
            
            2. **Soil Improvement:**
               - Add clay or silt-rich soil to improve texture
               - Incorporate very high rates of organic matter (30-40 tonnes/ha)
               - Use cocopeat or vermiculite as soil amendments
            
            3. **Crop-Specific Recommendations:**
               - **For Onions:** Consider container or raised bed cultivation
               - **For Tomatoes:** Use salt-tolerant varieties and mulching

results.recommendations:
### Recommendations for Alluvial Soil:
            
            1. **Maintenance Practices:**
               - Add organic matter annually (10-15 tonnes/ha)
               - Implement crop rotation with legumes
               - Use conservation tillage practices
            
            2. **Nutrient Management:**
               - Apply balanced fertilizers based on soil test results
               - Use micronutrient supplements if deficiency symptoms appear
               - Implement split application of nitrogen
            
            3. **Crop-Specific Recommendations:**
               - **For Onions:** Regular but controlled irrigation to prevent disease
               - **For Tomatoes:** Stake plants and maintain optimal spacing

results.recommendations:
### Recommendations for Laterite Soil:
            
            1. **pH Correction:**
               - Apply agricultural lime (1-2 tonnes/ha)
               - Use dolomitic lime for magnesium supplementation
               - Retest soil pH after 3-4 months
            
            2. **Fertility Enhancement:**
               - Incorporate high rates of organic matter (25-30 tonnes/ha)
               - Apply rock phosphate for slow phosphorus release
               - Use balanced NPK fertilizers with micronutrients
            
            3. **Crop-Specific Recommendations:**
               - **For Onions:** Create raised beds with amended soil mixture
               - **For Tomatoes:** Apply vermicompost and use mulching

results.recommendations:
### Recommendations for Red Soil:
            
            1. **Organic Matter Enhancement:**
               - Add compost or well-rotted manure (20-25 tonnes/ha)
               - Implement green manuring practices
               - Use mulching to conserve soil moisture
            
            2. **Nutrient Management:**
               - Apply balanced NPK fertilizers
               - Incorporate micronutrient mixtures containing zinc, boron, and manganese
               - Use split application of nitrogen fertilizers
            
            3. **Crop-Specific Recommendations:**
               - **For Onions:** Ensure regular water supply and add potassium fertilizers
               - **For Tomatoes:** Apply calcium-rich amendments to prevent blossom end rot

results.recommendations:
### Recommendations for Coastal Sandy Soil:
            
            1. **Water Management:**
               - Install drip irrigation systems
               - Use mulching extensively to conserve moisture
               - Apply hydrogels for improving water retention
            
            2. **Soil Improvement:**
               - Add clay or silt-rich soil to improve texture
               - Incorporate very high rates of organic matter (30-40 tonnes/ha)
               - Use cocopeat or vermiculite as soil amendments
            
            3. **Crop-Specific Recommendations:**
               - **For Onions:** Consider container or raised bed cultivation
               - **For Tomatoes:** Use salt-tolerant varieties and mulching

diseases.name: Early Blight
diseases.description: Dark brown lesions with concentric rings (target-like) on lower leaves spreading upward
diseases.treatment: Apply appropriate Chlorothalonil, Azoxystrobin or organic options: Copper hydroxide, Neem oil

detailed_info.symptoms: Dark brown spots with concentric rings on older leaves ('target board' appearance). Yellowing of leaves leading to defoliation
detailed_info.causes: Fungus (Alternaria solani) persists in soil and plant debris. Spread facilitated by splashing water and wind
detailed_info.treatment: Spray Chlorothalonil or Mancozeb @ 2–2.5 g/L. Use Azoxystrobin as systemic option
detailed_info.prevention: Practice crop rotation, remove plant debris after harvest, ensure balanced fertilization (especially nitrogen and potassium)

pests.name: Tomato Hornworm
pests.scientific_name: Manduca quinquemaculata
pests.description: Large (up to 10cm) green caterpillars with diagonal white stripes and a horn-like projection. Extensive defoliation, feeding on fruits, significant damage to tomato plants
pests.treatment: Chemical control: Carbaryl, Permethrin. Organic options: Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt), Handpicking

pests.name: Thrips
pests.scientific_name: Various species (e.g., Thrips tabaci, Frankliniella occidentalis)
pests.description: Tiny (1-2mm), slender insects with fringed wings, difficult to see without magnification. Silvery stippling on leaves, leaf distortion, scarring of fruits, transmission of viruses
pests.treatment: Chemical control: Spinosad, Spinetoram. Organic options: Spinosad, Neem oil

preventive_measures: Use reflective mulch to reduce landing rates
Use blue sticky traps to monitor and trap adults
Remove and destroy infected plant parts immediately
Apply appropriate fungicide/bactericide for the specific pathogen
Improve growing conditions to reduce disease pressure
Implement physical barriers or traps for the specific pest
Apply appropriate insecticide following IPM principles
Enhance natural enemy populations through habitat management
Use floating row covers until flowering to prevent early pest damage
Install reflective mulch to repel aphids and whiteflies (50% reduction)

fertilizer_recommendations.name: Balanced NPK (10-10-10)
fertilizer_recommendations.description: Provides equal parts nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), and potassium (K). Nitrogen promotes leaf growth, phosphorus supports root and flower development, potassium enhances overall plant health.
fertilizer_recommendations.application: Apply 2-3 lbs per 100 sq ft before planting and side-dress during active growth. Water thoroughly after application.
fertilizer_recommendations.conditions: General purpose for most plants during vegetative growth
fertilizer_recommendations.scientific_backing: University studies show balanced NPK improves yield by 15-20% over unfertilized controls

fertilizer_recommendations.conditions: For fruiting stage, especially when blossom end rot is a concern
fertilizer_recommendations.scientific_backing: Reduces blossom end rot incidence by up to 80% in field trials

fertilizer_recommendations.description: Lower nitrogen with higher potassium for bulb development phase. Reducing nitrogen prevents excess leaf growth that can delay bulbing.

fertilizer_recommendations.conditions: During bulb formation stage
fertilizer_recommendations.scientific_backing: Potassium application at bulbing improves storage quality by 25-40%

preventive_measures: Cure harvested bulbs properly with good ventilation to prevent storage diseases
Apply sulfur-containing fertilizers to enhance pungency and disease resistance
Practice shallow cultivation to avoid damaging shallow root systems
Introduce beneficial insects 2 weeks before expected pest outbreaks

Monitor plants weekly with a 10x magnifier for early pest/disease detection
Water at the base in early morning (reduces leaf wetness duration by 60%)
Apply 2-3 inches of organic mulch (reduces soil-borne disease splash by 75%)

diseases.name: Early Blight
diseases.description: Dark brown lesions with concentric rings (target-like) on lower leaves spreading upward
diseases.treatment: Apply appropriate Chlorothalonil, Azoxystrobin or organic options: Copper hydroxide, Neem oil

detailed_info.symptoms: Dark brown spots with concentric rings on older leaves ('target board' appearance). Yellowing of leaves leading to defoliation
detailed_info.causes: Fungus (Alternaria solani) persists in soil and plant debris. Spread facilitated by splashing water and wind
detailed_info.treatment: Spray Chlorothalonil or Mancozeb @ 2–2.5 g/L. Use Azoxystrobin as systemic option
detailed_info.prevention: Practice crop rotation, remove plant debris after harvest, ensure balanced fertilization (especially nitrogen and potassium)

pests.name: Tomato Hornworm
pests.scientific_name: Manduca quinquemaculata
pests.description: Large (up to 10cm) green caterpillars with diagonal white stripes and a horn-like projection. Extensive defoliation, feeding on fruits, significant damage to tomato plants
pests.treatment: Chemical control: Carbaryl, Permethrin. Organic options: Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt), Handpicking

pests.name: Thrips
pests.scientific_name: Various species (e.g., Thrips tabaci, Frankliniella occidentalis)
pests.description: Tiny (1-2mm), slender insects with fringed wings, difficult to see without magnification. Silvery stippling on leaves, leaf distortion, scarring of fruits, transmission of viruses
pests.treatment: Chemical control: Spinosad, Spinetoram. Organic options: Spinosad, Neem oil

preventive_measures: Use blue sticky traps to monitor and trap adults
Avoid planting near known host plants like onions and garlic
Remove and destroy infected plant parts immediately
Apply appropriate fungicide/bactericide for the specific pathogen
Improve growing conditions to reduce disease pressure
Implement physical barriers or traps for the specific pest
Apply appropriate insecticide following IPM principles
Enhance natural enemy populations through habitat management
Prune to 2-3 main stems for optimal airflow (reduces disease pressure 30%)
Stake plants at 45° angle for maximum sun exposure and air flow

fertilizer_recommendations.conditions: When plants are transitioning from vegetative to flowering stage
fertilizer_recommendations.scientific_backing: Improves fruit set by 25-30% compared to high-nitrogen fertilizers

results.recommendations:
### Recommendations for Coastal Sandy Soil:
            
            1. **Water Management:**
               - Install drip irrigation systems
               - Use mulching extensively to conserve moisture
               - Apply hydrogels for improving water retention
            
            2. **Soil Improvement:**
               - Add clay or silt-rich soil to improve texture
               - Incorporate very high rates of organic matter (30-40 tonnes/ha)
               - Use cocopeat or vermiculite as soil amendments
            
            3. **Crop-Specific Recommendations:**
               - **For Onions:** Consider container or raised bed cultivation
               - **For Tomatoes:** Use salt-tolerant varieties and mulching

results.recommendations:
### Recommendations for Laterite Soil:
            
            1. **pH Correction:**
               - Apply agricultural lime (1-2 tonnes/ha)
               - Use dolomitic lime for magnesium supplementation
               - Retest soil pH after 3-4 months
            
            2. **Fertility Enhancement:**
               - Incorporate high rates of organic matter (25-30 tonnes/ha)
               - Apply rock phosphate for slow phosphorus release
               - Use balanced NPK fertilizers with micronutrients
            
            3. **Crop-Specific Recommendations:**
               - **For Onions:** Create raised beds with amended soil mixture
               - **For Tomatoes:** Apply vermicompost and use mulching

results.recommendations:
### Recommendations for Laterite Soil:
            
            1. **pH Correction:**
               - Apply agricultural lime (1-2 tonnes/ha)
               - Use dolomitic lime for magnesium supplementation
               - Retest soil pH after 3-4 months
            
            2. **Fertility Enhancement:**
               - Incorporate high rates of organic matter (25-30 tonnes/ha)
               - Apply rock phosphate for slow phosphorus release
               - Use balanced NPK fertilizers with micronutrients
            
            3. **Crop-Specific Recommendations:**
               - **For Onions:** Create raised beds with amended soil mixture
               - **For Tomatoes:** Apply vermicompost and use mulching

diseases.name: Powdery Mildew
diseases.description: Symptoms of Powdery Mildew observed on the plant
diseases.treatment: Consult a local agricultural expert for specific treatment options

pests.name: Tomato Hornworm
pests.scientific_name: Manduca quinquemaculata
pests.description: Large (up to 10cm) green caterpillars with diagonal white stripes and a horn-like projection. Extensive defoliation, feeding on fruits, significant damage to tomato plants
pests.treatment: Chemical control: Carbaryl, Permethrin. Organic options: Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt), Handpicking

pests.name: Thrips
pests.scientific_name: Various species (e.g., Thrips tabaci, Frankliniella occidentalis)
pests.description: Tiny (1-2mm), slender insects with fringed wings, difficult to see without magnification. Silvery stippling on leaves, leaf distortion, scarring of fruits, transmission of viruses
pests.treatment: Chemical control: Spinosad, Spinetoram. Organic options: Spinosad, Neem oil

preventive_measures: Time plantings to avoid peak spore dispersal periods
Plant resistant varieties with Pm genes where available
Use reflective mulch to reduce landing rates
Avoid planting near known host plants like onions and garlic
Implement physical barriers or traps for the specific pest
Apply appropriate insecticide following IPM principles
Enhance natural enemy populations through habitat management
Rotate crops following scientific rotation schedules (minimum 3-year cycle)
Water at the base in early morning (reduces leaf wetness duration by 60%)
Maintain optimal plant spacing for good air circulation (prevents 85% of fungal issues)

fertilizer_recommendations.name: Compost Tea
fertilizer_recommendations.description: Liquid extract of compost containing beneficial microbes, nutrients, and organic compounds that improve soil biology and plant health.
fertilizer_recommendations.application: Apply as soil drench (5 gal/100 sq ft) or foliar spray (diluted 1:5) every 2-4 weeks.
fertilizer_recommendations.conditions: All plants, especially when microbial activity is desired
fertilizer_recommendations.scientific_backing: Research demonstrates 30-50% increase in beneficial soil microbes after application

fertilizer_recommendations.name: Balanced NPK (10-10-10)
fertilizer_recommendations.description: Provides equal parts nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), and potassium (K). Nitrogen promotes leaf growth, phosphorus supports root and flower development, potassium enhances overall plant health.
fertilizer_recommendations.application: Apply 2-3 lbs per 100 sq ft before planting and side-dress during active growth. Water thoroughly after application.
fertilizer_recommendations.conditions: General purpose for most plants during vegetative growth
fertilizer_recommendations.scientific_backing: University studies show balanced NPK improves yield by 15-20% over unfertilized controls

fertilizer_recommendations.name: Rock Phosphate
fertilizer_recommendations.description: Slow-release source of phosphorus that becomes available over 2-3 years. Ideal for building long-term soil phosphorus reserves.
fertilizer_recommendations.application: Apply 5-10 lbs per 100 sq ft and incorporate into soil before planting. Does not dissolve in water.
fertilizer_recommendations.conditions: Soils testing low in phosphorus, perennial crops
fertilizer_recommendations.scientific_backing: Long-term studies show cumulative benefits over 3-5 year period

preventive_measures: Cure harvested bulbs properly with good ventilation to prevent storage diseases
Plant disease-free sets or transplants from certified sources
Apply sulfur-containing fertilizers to enhance pungency and disease resistance
Water at the base in early morning (reduces leaf wetness duration by 60%)
Introduce beneficial insects 2 weeks before expected pest outbreaks
Monitor plants weekly with a 10x magnifier for early pest/disease detection
Use drip irrigation instead of overhead (reduces disease spread by 40%)
Rotate crops following scientific rotation schedules (minimum 3-year cycle)

fertilizer_recommendations.name: Rock Phosphate

fertilizer_recommendations.application: Apply 5-10 lbs per 100 sq ft and incorporate into soil before planting. Does not dissolve in water.
fertilizer_recommendations.conditions: Soils testing low in phosphorus, perennial crops
fertilizer_recommendations.scientific_backing: Long-term studies show cumulative benefits over 3-5 year period

fertilizer_recommendations.name: Nitrogen-Sulfur Blend
fertilizer_recommendations.description: Provides nitrogen for leaf growth and sulfur which is essential for onion flavor development and disease resistance.
fertilizer_recommendations.application: Side-dress 1 lb/100 ft row at 3-leaf stage and again 3-4 weeks later.
fertilizer_recommendations.conditions: Early to mid-growth stage onions
fertilizer_recommendations.scientific_backing: Sulfur application increases pyruvic acid content by 30%, enhancing flavor

fertilizer_recommendations.name: Low-N, High-K Blend
fertilizer_recommendations.description: Lower nitrogen with higher potassium for bulb development phase. Reducing nitrogen prevents excess leaf growth that can delay bulbing.
fertilizer_recommendations.application: Apply 1 lb/100 ft row when bulbs begin to form, typically 6-8 weeks after planting.
fertilizer_recommendations.conditions: During bulb formation stage
fertilizer_recommendations.scientific_backing: Potassium application at bulbing improves storage quality by 25-40%

diseases.name: Early Blight
diseases.description: Dark brown lesions with concentric rings (target-like) on lower leaves spreading upward
diseases.treatment: Apply appropriate Chlorothalonil, Azoxystrobin or organic options: Copper hydroxide, Neem oil

detailed_info.symptoms: Dark brown spots with concentric rings on older leaves ('target board' appearance). Yellowing of leaves leading to defoliation
detailed_info.causes: Fungus (Alternaria solani) persists in soil and plant debris. Spread facilitated by splashing water and wind
detailed_info.treatment: Spray Chlorothalonil or Mancozeb @ 2–2.5 g/L. Use Azoxystrobin as systemic option
detailed_info.prevention: Practice crop rotation, remove plant debris after harvest, ensure balanced fertilization (especially nitrogen and potassium)

diseases.name: Fusarium Wilt
diseases.description: Yellowing and wilting of lower leaves, often on one side of the plant, vascular discoloration
diseases.treatment: Apply: Propiconazole, Thiophanate-methyl

detailed_info.symptoms: Yellowing and wilting of leaves, often on one side of the plant. Brown discoloration of vascular tissue when stems are cut
detailed_info.causes: Soil-borne fungus Fusarium oxysporum enters through roots and blocks water transport
detailed_info.treatment: Use biofertilizers like Pseudomonas fluorescens, Neem Cake + Farm Yard Manure (FYM)
detailed_info.prevention: Plant resistant tomato varieties, practice crop rotation with non-host plants, remove and destroy infected plants
